pr_title: Ensure deposits are correctly ordered when creating the genesis state

timeline.message: Ensure deposits are correctly ordered when creating the genesis state.

timeline.author: mbaxter

timeline.bodyText: So, this test passes deterministically because we're sending exactly the right number of deposits to trigger genesis?
timeline.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText: Yes.  The new, improved version now can handle more than the required deposits as long as they're in different blocks (ie it doesn't include all transactions from a block if only some are required to trigger genesis).
replies.author: ajsutton

timeline.author: mbaxter
mbaxter

replies.bodyText: Alternatively, could we just make this a local variable within onDeposit and always set it to the last deposit's blockHash?
replies.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText: Doesn't matter now, but each @Subscribe method is called inside a synchronized block (specific to the method, not the class) so as long as the variables are only used as a result of a single event method, we can treat it as single threaded.
replies.author: ajsutton

timeline.message: Switch to queuing deposits so they are processed in order not just ordered correctly in the genesis state.
Split genesis creation into a separate class.
Extract queuing and reordering logic for deposits to a separate class so it can be tested in isolation.
We don't need the full transaction objects.
Remove genesisReady from StateProcessor as we can check directly with ChainStorageClient.
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:PegaSysEng/artemis into deposit-order

timeline.author: mbaxter

timeline.bodyText: First time seeing you use iterators. Why did you choose an iterator here?
timeline.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText: I needed to be able to remove items as I iterated. You can't just call pendingDeposits.remove because you'll get a ConcurrentAccessException so you have to use Iterator.remove (usually more efficient too because the iterator knows where it's up to).
replies.author: ajsutton

timeline.bodyText:
One thing I noticed in this PR, unrelated to this PR is that process slot gets called only when storeTime is greater than nextSlotStartTime. Since, at least with the current constants, onTick() gets called twice every second, in the worst-case scenario we're losing 500 ms processing time for each slot. I think we should fix this. Here's the ticket: https://pegasys1.atlassian.net/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=67&modal=detail&selectedIssue=BC-244
One idea is to have a SlotScheduler class that has its own timer which gets kicked off exactly at genesis. This class could post SlotEvents, BroadcastAttestationEvents and BroadcastAggregateEvents just like the processSlot method here, however, it would post those events way more precisely.
timeline.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText: Yep, definitely some improvements to be made around here.  I've been thinking of having a separate TimeService that fires time, slot and epoch events in.  Would need to do more thinking and playing to know if that will really work, but it's appealing in terms of being able to start doing time travel in tests because it's a single source of where time is up to.
replies.author: ajsutton

replies.bodyText: Agreed. A separate TimeService is a good direction.
replies.author: cemozerr
